Cancer (various types, including lung cancer and lymphoma)
Viral Infection (such as Epstein-Barr virus or Cytomegalovirus)

Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Chronic Back Pain – related to musculoskeletal disorders, degenerative disc disease, or chronic strain.
Cysts – depending on location, can be related to benign growths, sebaceous cysts, epidermoid cysts, or complex cysts potentially related to cancers.
Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy – often preceded by stressful events or emotional stress, leading to temporary heart dysfunction mimicking a heart attack.
Monocytosis – could indicate chronic inflammation, infection, stress response, or hematologic diseases like chronic myelomonocytic leukemia.
Wheezing – associated with asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), allergic reactions, or airway obstructions.
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) – could be investigated due to the presenting symptom of wheezing, especially if there's a history of smoking or long-term exposure to lung irritants.
Asthma – consideration given to wheezing, which is a common symptom, possibly exacerbated by stress or allergic reactions.
Fibromyalgia – considering chronic back pain, and possibly related to stress as seen in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Requires a diagnosis of exclusion.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – considering the combination of symptoms, SLE could be an underlying cause. It’s an autoimmune disease that may present with a wide range of symptoms, including musculoskeletal pain, skin manifestations, and cardiac effects.

Sarcoidosis – might be considered due to the variety of symptoms that can affect multiple organs including lungs (wheezing), skin (cysts), heart (Takotsubo cardiomyopathy), and it can sometimes lead to an elevation in monocyte count.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Secondary immunodeficiency due to external agent

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause fibrosis, affect mental health leading to obsessive-compulsive behavior, and cause lymphadenopathy due to immune system activity.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease leading to fibrosis of the skin and possibly internal organs, which may indirectly cause digestive issues such as bloating.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: Includes conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, which can cause bloating, and may indirectly lead to lymphadenopathy due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in lymph nodes causing lymphadenopathy or lymphadenitis, and can cause bloating due to lymphatic system blockage.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A viral infection attacking the immune system, leading to lymphadenopathy among other symptoms. Mental health issues including obsessive-compulsive behavior can also develop.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can cause fibrosis in various organs, lymphadenopathy, and often affects mental health.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal carcinoma
diagnoses.description: Cancers of the gastrointestinal tract can cause bloating and may result in lymphadenopathy due to metastasis or direct lymphatic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, leading to symptoms including lymphadenopathy and potentially affecting the body's ability to manage stress and mental health.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing bloating and potentially lymphadenopathy due to immune response.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can cause lymphadenitis as the body's immune system fights the infection, sometimes leading to mental health issues due to chronic illness.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like headache, aphasia, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe. Associated symptoms can include nausea and difficulties with speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor caused by abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, either in the brain itself, the cranial nerves, the brain envelopes, skull, pituitary, and pineal gland. Symptoms may include headache, nausea, and aphasia, depending on the tumor’s location.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those you'd have in a stroke, including headache, aphasia, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An acute inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. Symptoms can include headache, nausea, and neurologic deficits such as aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Symptoms include headache, nausea, fever, confusion, and in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a diseased blood vessel within the brain bursts, allowing blood to leak inside the brain. Symptoms can include sudden headache, nausea, and neurological deficits like aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Aphasia can be a symptom if the electrical disturbance occurs in language areas of the brain.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A focal, suppurative infection within the brain parenchyma, which can cause symptoms such as headache, nausea, fever, and in some cases, speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding into the subarachnoid space—the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and neurological impairments like aphasia.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (for psychosis, considering it as a separate symptom)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
